subject: Public Speaking
title: Data Visualization as Modern Rhetoric
description: A 60-second lesson on Data Visualization as Modern Rhetoric.

hook.text: Al Gore showed a graph of CO2 levels in An Inconvenient Truth. The image did more persuading than any sentence.

buildup.text: Charts and graphs are rhetorical devices. They frame data in ways that highlight certain truths and hide others.

discovery.text: A graph with a truncated Y-axis makes a small change look dramatic. A zoomed-out graph can make a crisis look trivial.

twist.text: Audiences trust charts because they look objective. But every chart is an argumentâ€”someone chose what to show and hide.

climax.text: Visual rhetoric is the newest frontier. In a data-rich world, the person who controls the chart controls the narrative.

punchline.text: A chart is an argument wearing a lab coat.

quiz.question: Why are charts and graphs rhetorical devices?
options: They frame data by choosing what to show and what to hide
